Multiple fullscreen captures

Jeroen Janssens

2020-04-07

Source: vignettes/examples/asciinema.Rmd
asciinema.Rmd
knitractive::start("bash",
                   prompt = tmuxr::prompts$bash,
                   docker_image = "ubuntu:bionic",
                   session_width = 100,
                   session_height = 16)
$ top

Normally, the screen “scrolls” after the output has been captured. This can be prevented by specifying the chunk option scroll = FALSE, which is especially useful for making multiple captures of fullscreen interfaces like top.

top - 12:38:58 up 2 days, 23:32,  0 users,  load average: 0.02, 0.03, 0.00
Tasks:   2 total,   1 running,   1 sleeping,   0 stopped,   0 zombie
%Cpu(s):  0.1 us,  0.3 sy,  0.0 ni, 99.5 id,  0.0 wa,  0.0 hi,  0.0 si,  0.0 st
KiB Mem :  4042328 total,   246032 free,  1652552 used,  2143744 buff/cache
KiB Swap:  1048572 total,  1048440 free,      132 used.  2100700 avail Mem
 
  PID USER      PR  NI    VIRT    RES    SHR S  %CPU %MEM     TIME+ COMMAND
    1 root      20   0   18504   3444   3032 S   0.0  0.1   0:00.06 bash
    9 root      20   0   36484   3132   2740 R   0.0  0.1   0:00.00 top

Scrolling is needed only after the last capture, so with the next chunk, we don’t specify scroll = FALSE.

top - 12:38:58 up 2 days, 23:32,  0 users,  load average: 0.02, 0.03, 0.00
Tasks:   2 total,   1 running,   1 sleeping,   0 stopped,   0 zombie
%Cpu(s):  0.1 us,  0.3 sy,  0.0 ni, 99.5 id,  0.0 wa,  0.0 hi,  0.0 si,  0.0 st
KiB Mem :  4042328 total,   246032 free,  1652552 used,  2143744 buff/cache
KiB Swap:  1048572 total,  1048440 free,      132 used.  2100700 avail Mem
 
  PID USER      PR  NI    VIRT    RES    SHR S  %CPU %MEM     TIME+ COMMAND
    1 root      20   0   18504   3444   3032 S   0.0  0.1   0:00.06 bash
    9 root      20   0   36484   3132   2740 R   0.0  0.1   0:00.00 top
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
$ seq 10

3

$ parallel --citation
Academic tradition requires you to cite works you base your article on.
When using programs that use GNU Parallel to process data for publication
please cite:
 
@article{Tange2011a,
  title = {GNU Parallel - The Command-Line Power Tool},
  author = {O. Tange},
  address = {Frederiksberg, Denmark},
  journal = {;login: The USENIX Magazine},
  month = {Feb},
  number = {1},
  volume = {36},
  url = {http://www.gnu.org/s/parallel},
  year = {2011},
  pages = {42-47},
  doi = {http://dx.doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.16303}
}
 
(Feel free to use \nocite{Tange2011a})
 
This helps funding further development; AND IT WON'T COST YOU A CENT.
If you pay 10000 EUR you should feel free to use GNU Parallel without citing.
 
If you send a copy of your published article to tange@gnu.org, it will be
mentioned in the release notes of next version of GNU Parallel.
 
 
 
Type: 'will cite' and press enter.
> will cite
 
Thank you for your support. It is much appreciated. The citation
notice is now silenced.
 
$ seq 3 | parallel --bar 'sleep 1'
